column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/02/new-baker-or-fluke-baker/|New Baker Or Fluke Baker?|A lot of Bucs fans are wondering if 2024 rookies Jalen McMillan and Bucky Irving can improve on their stunning stats next season. Joe is just as focused on another guy and one aspect of his game. That’s Baker Mayfield. Mayfield ran for 378 yards last season
column2: more than double his previous career high. His escape skills and quality scrambling were key pieces of the Bucs’ offense. Mayfield also rushed for 24 first downs
column3: another career high big a big margin. And guess who led the NFL in fumbles last season? Mayfield tied for the league lead with 13
column4: a career high by a mile. So Joe’s wondering if Mayfield’s scrambling can and will continue at this high-octane
column5: high-performance pace. And do the Bucs want Mayfield on the move? Rookie offensive coordinator Josh Grizzard told Joe and other reporters in an off-podium chat at One Buc Palace that Mayfield can improve by cutting turnovers. (He tied for the 2024 league lead in interceptions.) Maybe that means taking fewer chances and throwing balls away more often. If Mayfield goes back to his more typical 160 or so rushing yards per season
column6: Joe would be just fine with that
column7: though the Bucs will have to find ways to recapture the lost production.|2025-02-23 22:02:00|210|28|5|Baker Mayfield|Speculation on Mayfield's scrambling ability and turnovers for upcoming season.|5|Mixed sentiments on turnovers

column2: and he’s grateful his quarterback didn’t scream at him for his failures last season. Baker Mayfield was emphatic and supportive
column3: Barton told SiriusXM NFL Radio last week. “Baker’s big thing with me coming in was he knew how much my head was spinning trying to learn the entire offense and learn the position and learn all that stuff at once
column6: I can’t say enough about how awesome Baker was to me this year. I’m sure there were many a times where I deserved to get an ass-chewing from Baker. But
column8: he chose to just put confidence in me and help me learn and make sure we’re on the same page together. “He never brought be down. It was always about just giving me confidence. So Baker was really patient with me
column9: and he had a lot of belief in me.” Lots of unity and love within the Bucs roster. It’s helped pull the team out of tough times the past two seasons. Hopefully

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/02/bspn-bucs-better-off-without-rachaad-white/|BSPN: Bucs Better Off Without Rachaad White|Joe tries to think objectively
column2: when it’s reasonable to think objectively. For example
column3: Joe’s mind shuts down if anyone tries to insist NFL teams can win it all without the need of a quarterback or strong production from an edge rusher. Good luck with that. Joe has a lot of respect for Aaron Schatz
column4: the inventor of DVOA and creator of Football Outsiders (RIP). He now is a force behind FTN Data and still contributes to BSPN. In his latest offering for the four-letter
column5: Schatz thinks that since Rachaad White is a No. 2 back
column6: his salary (and cap hit) can be put to much better use if the Bucs are hoping to build their roster for a Super Bowl run. Cut Rachaad White The Buccaneers enter free agency with only $2.2 million in cap space. They need to make some room and one way to do it is to say goodbye to White. The running back is entering the final year of his rookie contract
column7: so the Buccaneers can cut him for $3.3 million in cap savings with less than $250
column8: 000 in dead money. White is still a useful player
column9: but he gradually lost the No. 1 spot to Bucky Irving in 2024. White had positive rushing yards over expected
column10: according to NFL Next Gen Stats
column11: but he was far behind Irving. (White had 0.34 RYOE per carry
column12: while Irving was at 0.94.) White was an excellent receiving back
column13: ranking fifth in total receiving value by my DYAR metric
column14: but Irving was eighth. The Buccaneers need to save money somewhere
column15: and this is where it wouldn’t hurt too much. The more Joe thinks of this the more Joe is open-minded. If the Bucs would use White’s salary to bring in a stud edge rusher
column16: this move has to be seriously considered. Think about it: Who would have more of an impact
column17: an edge rusher who can consistently put heat on and make a quarterback eat dirt regularly
column18: or White being a part-time player? For Joe
column19: the answer is obvious. But Schatz is also correct that White is a very dangerous pass catcher. And he can pass block
column20: which many fans overlook. That is a critical trait NFL folks rarely dismiss. With a new offensive coordinator coming in
column21: the more weapons Josh Grizzard can have to smooth the transition the better. And White
column24: a solid full-time edge rusher or a part-time back? Joe knows which holds more weight. Getting rid of White only makes sense if there is a major upgrade for an impact player at a defensive starting position. Maybe the easiest solution is to rework White’s contract
column25: but that likely would require a contract extension the Bucs aren’t interested in handing out.|2025-02-23 00:00:00|463|70|7|Rachaad White|Bucs consider cutting White to free up cap for upgrades.|5|Mixed opinions on cutting or trading Rachaad White
